head.title: Constraints on Cosmological Parameters from the LyÎ± Forest Power Spectrum and COBE-DMR

article.h1: Constraints on Cosmological Parameters from the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha Forest Power Spectrum and COBE-DMR

div.p: We combine COBE-DMR measurements of cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropy with a recent measurement of the mass power spectrum at redshift z=2.5ğ‘§2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5 from LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest data to derive constraints on cosmological parameters and test the inflationary cold dark matter (CDM) scenario of structure formation. By treating the inflationary spectral index nğ‘›italic-nn as a free parameter, we are able to find successful fits to the COBE and LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest constraints in Î©m=1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1 models with and without massive neutrinos and in low-Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} models with and without a cosmological constant. Within each class of model, the combination of COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constrains a parameter combination of the form Î©mâ¢hÎ±â¢nÎ²â¢Î©bÎ³subscriptÎ©ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ›¼superscriptğ‘›ğ›½superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘ğ›¾Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}\Omega_{b}^{\gamma}, with different indices for each case. This new constraint breaks some of the degeneracies in cosmological parameter determinations from other measurements of large scale structure and CMB anisotropy. The LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) provides the first measurement of the slope of the linear mass power spectrum on âˆ¼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim\;Mpc scales, Î½=-2.25Â±0.18ğœˆplus-or-minus2.250.18italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.18\nu=-2.25\pm 0.18, and it confirms a basic prediction of the inflationary CDM scenario: an approximately scale-invariant spectrum of primeval fluctuations (nâ‰ˆ1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1n\approx 1) modulated by a transfer function that bends Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) towards kn-4superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›4italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk^{n-4} on small scales. Considering additional observational data, we find that COBE-normalized, Î©m=1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1 models that match the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) do not match the observed masses of rich galaxy clusters and that low-Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} models with a cosmological constant provide the best overall fit to the available data, even without the direct evidence for cosmic acceleration from Type Ia supernovae. With our fiducial parameter choices, the flat, low-Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} models that match COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) also match recent measurements of small scale CMB anisotropy. Modest improvements in the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement could greatly restrict the allowable region of parameter space for CDM models, constrain the contribution of tensor fluctuations to CMB anisotropy, and achieve a more stringent test of the current consensus model of structure formation.

div.p: Cosmological models based on cold dark matter (CDM) and simple versions of inflation have had considerable success in accounting for the origin of cosmic structure. In this class of models, the primordial density fluctuations are Gaussian distributed, and the shape of their power spectrum is determined by a small number of physical parameters that describe the inflationary fluctuations themselves and the material contents of the universe. For specified cosmological parameters, the measurement of cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies by the COBE-DMR experiment (smoot92 ; bennett96 ) fixes the amplitude of the matter power spectrum on large scales with an uncertainty of âˆ¼20%similar-toabsentpercent20RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:20 POSTFIX:percent\sim 20\% (e.g., bunn97 ). In this paper, we combine the COBE normalization with a recent measurement of the matter power spectrum by Croft et al.Â (1999b, hereafter CWPHK) to test the inflation+CDM scenario and constrain its physical parameters. A modified version of the method developed here is applied to a more recent power spectrum measurement by Croft et al.Â (2001).

CWPHK infer the mass power spectrum Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) from measurements of LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest absorption in the light of background quasars, at a mean absorption redshift zâ‰ˆ2.5ğ‘§2.5italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:2.5z\approx 2.5. The method, introduced by Croft et al.Â (1998), is based on the physical picture of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest that has emerged in recent years from 3-dimensional, hydrodynamic cosmological simulations and related analytic models (e.g., cen94 ; Zhang (Anninos); hernquist96 ; bi97 ; Hui (Gnedin)). By focusing on the absorption from diffuse intergalactic gas in mildly non-linear structures, this method sidesteps the complicated theoretical problem of biased galaxy formation; it directly estimates the linear theory mass power spectrum (over a limited range of scales) under the assumption of Gaussian initial conditions. Because the observational units are km s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}, the CWPHK measurement probes somewhat different comoving scales for different cosmological parameters: Î»â‰¡2â¢Ï€/k=2-12â¢h-1â¢Mpcğœ†2ğœ‹ğ‘˜212superscriptâ„1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equivalent-to NUMBER:2 italic-pi MULOP:divide italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda\equiv 2\pi/k=2-12{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=1, Î»=3-16â¢h-1â¢Mpcğœ†316superscriptâ„1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:16 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda=3-16{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=0.55 and Î©Î›subscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0, and Î»=4-22â¢h-1â¢Mpcğœ†422superscriptâ„1Mpcitalic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:22 italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc\lambda=4-22{h^{-1}{\rm Mpc}\;} for Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}=0.4 and Î©Î›subscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0.6 (hâ‰¡H0/100â¢kmâ¢s-1â¢Mpc-1â„subscriptğ»0100kmsuperscripts1superscriptMpc1italic-h RELOP:equivalent-to italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:100 km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Mpc POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endh\equiv H_{0}/100\;{\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}}\;{\rm Mpc}^{-1}). CWPHK determine the logarithmic slope of Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) on these scales with an uncertainty âˆ¼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2 and the amplitude with an uncertainty âˆ¼35%similar-toabsentpercent35RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:35 POSTFIX:percent\sim 35\%. The extensive tests on simulations in Croft et al.Â (1998) and CWPHK suggest that the statistical uncertainties quoted here dominate over systematic errors in the method itself, though the measurement does depend on the assumption of Gaussian primordial fluctuations and on the broad physical picture of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest described in the references above. For brevity, we will usually refer to the CWPHK determination of the mass power spectrum as â€œthe LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k).â€

In the next Section, we discuss our choice of the parameter space for inflationary CDM models. The core of the paper is Section 3, where we combine the COBE normalization with the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) to identify acceptable regions of the CDM parameter space. We focus on four representative models: a low density (Î©m<1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}<1) open model, a low density flat model with a cosmological constant, and Einstein-de Sitter (Î©m=1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}=1) models with pure CDM and with a mixture of CDM and hot dark matter. Because different parameters have nearly degenerate influences on the predicted LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), we are able to summarize our results in terms of simple equations that constrain combinations of these parameters. In Section 4, we consider other observational constraints that can break these degeneracies, such as the cluster mass function, the peculiar velocity power spectrum, the shape of the galaxy power spectrum, and the CMB anisotropy power spectrum. We review our conclusions in Section 5.

In simple inflationary models, the power spectrum of density fluctuations in the linear regime can be well approximated as a power law, Pâ¢(k)âˆknproportional-toğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(k)\propto k^{n} (where n=1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1 is the scale-invariant spectrum), multiplied by the square of a transfer function Tâ¢(k)ğ‘‡ğ‘˜italic-T OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)T(k) that depends on the relative energy densities of components with different equations of state. We will assume the standard radiation background (microwave background photons and three species of light neutrinos) and consider as other possible components cold dark matter, baryons, a â€œcosmological constantâ€ vacuum energy, and neutrinos with a non-zero rest mass in the few eV range. Within this class of models, the shape of the power spectrum is therefore determined by the parameters nğ‘›italic-nn, Î©CDMsubscriptÎ©CDMOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start CDM POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm CDM}, Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b}, Î©Î›subscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda}, Î©Î½subscriptÎ©ğœˆOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu}, and hâ„italic-hh (since Ïx=Î©xâ¢ÏcâˆÎ©xâ¢h2subscriptğœŒğ‘¥subscriptÎ©ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘proportional-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘¥superscriptâ„2italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-rho POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\rho_{x}=\Omega_{x}\rho_{c}\propto\Omega_{x}h^{2}). In place of Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b} and Î©CDMsubscriptÎ©CDMOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start CDM POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\rm CDM}, we use the parameters

div.p: Once the cosmological parameters are specified, normalizing to the results of the COBE-DMR experiment determines the amplitude of Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). For inflation models with n<1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1n<1, the COBE normalization can also be affected by the presence of tensor fluctuations (gravity waves). We consider normalizations with no tensor contribution and normalizations with the quadrupole tensor-to-scalar ratio T/S=7â¢(1-n)ğ‘‡ğ‘†71ğ‘›italic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n) predicted by simple power law inflation models (e.g., davis92 ), but we do not consider arbitrary tensor contributions. We compute the COBE-normalized, linear theory, matter power spectrum Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) using the convenient and accurate fitting formulas of Eisenstein & Hu (1999), with the normalization procedures of Bunn & White (1997) for all flat cases and for the open case without a tensor contribution and Hu & White (1997) for the open case with a tensor contribution.

There are plausible variants of this family of inflationary CDM models that we do not analyze in this paper, because we lack the tools to easily calculate their predictions and because they would make our parameter space intractably larger. Prominent among these variants are models with a time-varying scalar field, a.k.a. â€œquintessenceâ€ (e.g., peebles88 ; wang98 ), models in which the energy of the radiation background has been boosted above its standard value by a decaying particle species, a.k.a. â€œÏ„ğœitalic-tau\tauCDMâ€ (e.g., bond91 ), and models in which inflation produces a power spectrum with broken scale invariance (e.g., kates95 ). Given the observational evidence for a negative pressure component from Type Ia supernovae (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ), the quintessence family might be especially interesting to explore in future work.

In sum, the free parameters of our family of cosmological models are Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m}, hâ„italic-hh, nğ‘›italic-nn, Bğµitalic-BB, Î©Î½subscriptÎ©ğœˆOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu}, Î©Î›subscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda}, and T/Sğ‘‡ğ‘†italic-T MULOP:divide italic-ST/S. We allow Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m}, hâ„italic-hh, nğ‘›italic-nn, Bğµitalic-BB, and Î©Î½subscriptÎ©ğœˆOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\nu} to assume a continuous range of values. For Î©Î›subscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{\Lambda} and T/Sğ‘‡ğ‘†italic-T MULOP:divide italic-ST/S we consider only two discrete options: Î©Î›=0subscriptÎ©Î›0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Omega_{\Lambda}=0 or 1-Î©m1subscriptÎ©ğ‘šNUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1-\Omega_{m}, and T/S=0ğ‘‡ğ‘†0italic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T/S=0 or 7â¢(1-n)71ğ‘›NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)7(1-n).

section.h2: 3 Cosmological Parameters and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Forest P(k)

div.p: To organize our discussion and guide our analysis, we focus on variations about four fiducial models, each motivated by a combination of theoretical and observational considerations. The fiducial models are a flat cold dark matter model with a non-zero cosmological constant (Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM), an open cold dark matter model with no cosmological constant (OCDM), an Î©m=1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}=1 cold dark matter model with a significantly â€œtiltedâ€ inflationary spectrum (TCDM), and an Î©m=1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}=1 model with a mixture of cold and hot dark matter (CHDM).

Upper panels show models with no tensor fluctuations and lower panels show models with tensor fluctuations; the right hand panels zoom in on the range of wavenumbers probed by the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). The error bar on the open circle shows an overall normalization uncertainty in the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k); at the 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma level all of the points can shift up or down coherently by this amount. div.p: Figure 1 compares the power spectra of our fiducial models to the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), shown as the filled circles with error bars. Note that the overall normalization of the data points is uncertain; at the 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma level they can shift up or down coherently by the amount indicated by the error bar on the open circle (see CWPHK for details). The COBE normalization itself has a 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty of approximately 20% in Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), roughly half of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) normalization uncertainty. Panels (a) and (c) show the fiducial models with and without tensors, respectively, over a wide range of wavenumber. Panels (b) and (d) focus on the range of wavenumbers probed by the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Our first major result is already evident from Figure 1: all of the fiducial models reproduce the observed LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Each model has a single adjustable parameter, the spectral index nğ‘›italic-nn, so their success in reproducing both the amplitude and slope of Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) is an important confirmation of a generic prediction of the inflationary CDM scenario, a point we will return to shortly.
Within the precision and dynamic range of the CWPHK measurement, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) can be adequately described by a power law. CWPHK find

Briefly, the likelihood distribution for the slope, Î½ğœˆitalic-nu\nu, is derived by fitting the power law form (eq.Â 3) to the Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) data points, using their covariance matrix. Parameter changes have similar effects in all of the models, and these effects can be easily understood by considering the physics that determines the shape and normalization of the matter power spectrum. The CDM transfer function has a single fundamental scale câ¢teqğ‘subscriptğ‘¡eqitalic-c italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eq POSTSUBSCRIPT:endct_{m eq} determined by the size of the horizon at the time of matter-radiation equality; this scale is roughly the wavelength at which the power spectrum turns over. EquationÂ (7), together with TableÂ 2, is our second principal result, defining the quantitative constraints placed on the parameters of inflationary CDM models by the combination of COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Models with tensors are much more sensitive to nğ‘›italic-nn than models without tensors because of the influence of gravity waves on the Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) normalization, as discussed above. Although the index values are derived in all cases by considering small variations about the corresponding fiducial model, the constraint formulaÂ (7) remains accurate even for fairly large changes in the cosmological parameters. For example, plugging the TCDM values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, hâ„italic-hh, nğ‘›italic-nn, Bğµitalic-BB into equationÂ (7) with the Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM values of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha, Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta, and Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma yields k=0.47ğ‘˜0.47italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.47k=0.47, compared to the value k=0.44ğ‘˜0.44italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.44k=0.44 listed for Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM in TableÂ 2.

Recently McDonald et al.Â (2000) measured the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest flux power spectrum in a sample of eight Keck HIRES spectra and used it to infer the amplitude and shape of the mass power spectrum. Their mean absorption redshift is zâ‰ˆ3ğ‘§3italic-z RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:3z\approx 3 rather than z=2.5ğ‘§2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, and their data best constrain the Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) amplitude at k=0.04â¢(kmâ¢s-1)-1ğ‘˜0.04superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.04 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk=0.04\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1} rather than 0.008â¢(kmâ¢s-1)-10.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0.008\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1}. However, assuming gravitational instability and a CDM power spectrum shape, they extrapolate from their result to derive values of Î½ğœˆitalic-nu\nu and Î”2superscriptÎ”2Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta^{2} that can be directly compared to CWPHKâ€™s measurement at z=2.5ğ‘§2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, kp=0.008â¢(kmâ¢s-1)-1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘0.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk_{p}=0.008\;({\rm{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1}, obtaining Î½=-2.24Â±0.10ğœˆplus-or-minus2.240.10italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.24 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.10\nu=-2.24\pm 0.10 and Î”2â¢(kp)=0.32Â±0.07superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘plus-or-minus0.320.07Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.32 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.07\Delta^{2}(k_{p})=0.32\pm 0.07. Despite the entirely independent data sets and very different modelling procedures, the CWPHK and McDonald et al.Â (2000) measurements agree almost perfectly in slope and are consistent in amplitude at the âˆ¼1â¢Ïƒsimilar-toabsent1ğœRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\sim 1\sigma level. We plot the McDonald et al.Â (2000) measurement as error crosses in FiguresÂ 2 andÂ 3. McDonald et al.Â (2000) note that the small error bar on Î”2superscriptÎ”2Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta^{2} should be considered preliminary, since they have not fully investigated the sensitivity of their power spectrum normalization procedure to their modelling assumptions.

Clearly none of our qualitative conclusions about inflationary CDM models would change if we were to adopt the McDonald et al.Â (2000) Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) determination instead of the CWPHK determination. Conveniently, the McDonald et al.Â (2000) point lies almost exactly on our -1â¢Ïƒ1ğœADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma-1\sigma error contour, so to a good approximation one can obtain the parameter constraintsÂ (7) andÂ (8) implied by the McDonald et al.Â (2000) measurement by simply replacing the values of kğ‘˜italic-kk in TableÂ 2 by k-Ïµğ‘˜italic-Ïµitalic-k ADDOP:minus italic-epsilonk-\epsilon.

We have shown that the combination of COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) yields constraints on degenerate combinations of cosmological parameters. To break these degeneracies, we now consider observational constraints from other studies of large scale structure and CMB anisotropies. Analyses of cosmological parameter constraints from multiple observations have been carried out by numerous groups (recent examples include bahcall99 ; bridle99 ; Steigman (Hata); novosyadlyj00 ; Wang (Tegmark)). Our new contribution is to include the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) as one of the observational constraints (also considered by novosyadlyj00 and Wang (Tegmark)). We focus our attention on several other constraints that can be cast into a form that complements our results from Section 3: the mass function of galaxy clusters, the mass power spectrum inferred from galaxy peculiar velocities, the shape parameter of the galaxy power spectrum, and a constraint on nğ‘›italic-nn from CMB anisotropy data. Our discussion in this Section will be more qualitative than our discussion in Section 3, in part because the uncertainties in these constraints are largely systematic, so that a straightforward statistical combination could be misleading.

In each panel of FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, the heavy solid line shows the locus of (Î©m,n)subscriptÎ©ğ‘šğ‘›OPEN:( Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-n CLOSE:)({\Omega_{m}},n) values that yield a simultaneous match to COBE and the CWPHK measurement of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). These lines are very close to those implied by equationÂ (7) and TableÂ 2, but since those results are, strictly speaking, expansions about our fiducial model parameters, we compute the best-fit value of nğ‘›italic-nn exactly for each Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} rather than using equationÂ (7). The Â±1â¢Ïƒplus-or-minus1ğœADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\pm 1\sigma constraints are shown as the lighter solid lines; these are close to the curves implied by equationÂ (7) and TableÂ 2 with kğ‘˜italic-kk replaced by kÂ±Ïµplus-or-minusğ‘˜italic-Ïµitalic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilonk\pm\epsilon. Because the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint is not very sensitive to Bğµitalic-BB, we keep Bğµitalic-BB fixed at our fiducial value of 0.02 in all cases. We show results for h=0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65, h=0.45â„0.45italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.45h=0.45, and h=0.85â„0.85italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.85h=0.85 in the upper, middle, and lower panels of each figure, with flat and open models in the left and right hand columns, respectively. (2000) estimate of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) corresponds very closely to our -1â¢Ïƒ1ğœADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 italic-sigma-1\sigma constraint, so to adopt McDonald et al.Â (2000) instead of CWPHK one simply follows the lower solid line instead of the middle solid line as the constraint.

div.p: For Gaussian initial conditions, the space density of clusters as a function of virial mass constrains a combination of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and the mass fluctuation amplitude, since clusters of a given mass can be formed by the collapse of large volumes in a low density universe or smaller volumes in a higher density universe. This constraint can be summarized quite accurately in a formula relating Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} to the rms mass fluctuation Ïƒ8subscriptğœ8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} (White (Efstathiou)). We use the specific version of this formula obtained by Eke, Cole, & Frenk (1996, hereafter ECF) using N-body simulations and the Press-Schechter (1974) approximation:

CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end

div.p: For each value of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, we find the value of Ïƒ8subscriptğœ8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} required by the cluster mass function from equationÂ (9). Given hâ„italic-hh and B=0.02ğµ0.02italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.02B=0.02, we then find the value of nğ‘›italic-nn required to produce this value of Ïƒ8subscriptğœ8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} by numerically integrating the CDM power spectrum. This constraint in the Î©m-nsubscriptÎ©ğ‘šğ‘›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane is shown by the dotted line in each panel of FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, with an error bar that indicates the 8% uncertainty quoted in equationÂ (9) from ECF.

For a given value of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, the matter power spectrum can also be estimated from the statistics of galaxy peculiar motions. Freudling et al.Â (1998) apply a maximum likelihood technique to the SFI peculiar velocity catalog to constrain COBE-normalized, inflationary CDM models for the matter power spectrum, obtaining the constraint

div.p: where Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu, Î½ğœˆitalic-nu\nu, kğ‘˜italic-kk and Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon are dependent on the cosmology and h60â‰¡h/0.6subscriptâ„60â„0.6italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-h MULOP:divide NUMBER:0.6h_{60}\equiv h/0.6. In a flat, Î©Î›=1-Î©msubscriptÎ©Î›1subscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=1-{\Omega_{m}} model with no tensor component, (Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu, Î½ğœˆitalic-nu\nu, kğ‘˜italic-kk, Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon)=(1.3, 2.0, 0.58, 0.08), while if a tensor component is allowed they become (1.3, 3.9, 0.58, 0.08). For an open, Î©Î›=0subscriptÎ©Î›0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0 model without a tensor component they are (0.9, 1.4, 0.68, 0.07). Freudling et al.Â (1998) do not consider open, Î©Î›=0subscriptÎ©Î›0Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0{\Omega_{\Lambda}}=0 cases with a tensor component. For specified hâ„italic-hh, equationÂ (10) yields a constraint in the Î©m-nsubscriptÎ©ğ‘šğ‘›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane, shown by the short-dashed line in the panels of FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5. The associated 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars are based on the statistical uncertainties Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon quoted by Freudling et al.Â (1998) and listed above. For brevity, we will refer to these curves as the velocity power spectrum constraint, though they represent the constraints on the density power spectrum implied by peculiar velocites.

We do not want to use the amplitude of the galaxy power spectrum as one of our constraints because it can be strongly affected by biased galaxy formation. However, a variety of analytic and numerical arguments (e.g., coles93 ; fry93 ; Mann (Peacock); scherrer98 ; Narayanan (Berlind)) suggest that biased galaxy formation should not alter the shape of the galaxy power spectrum on scales in the linear regime, and on these scales the shape is directly related to the parameters of the inflationary CDM cosmology. We adopt the specific constraint found by Peacock & Dodds (1994) from their combined analysis of a number of galaxy clustering data sets:

semantics.annotation: Gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-h ARG:end ARG:end ARG:start Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.32 OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.255 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.017 PERIOD:.

div.p: For n=1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1, Î“eff=Î“subscriptÎ“effÎ“Gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals Gamma\Gamma_{\rm eff}=\Gamma, where Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma is the shape parameter in the conventional parameterization of the inflationary CDM power spectrum (bardeen86 ; the influence of Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{b}} is discussed by sugiyama95 ). While the effects of Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma and nğ‘›italic-nn on the power spectrum shape are different, equationÂ (11) combines them in a way that approximates their nearly degenerate influence over the range of scales currently probed by large scale clustering measurements. For specified hâ„italic-hh and Bğµitalic-BB, equationÂ (11) becomes a constraint in the Î©m-nsubscriptÎ©ğ‘šğ‘›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-n{\Omega_{m}}-n plane. We plot this constraint as the long-dashed line and associated error bar in the panels of FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5. We should note, however, that the Peacock & Dodds (1994) error bar may be overoptimistic, since independent estimates of Î“effsubscriptÎ“effGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff} often fall outside this range. Eisenstein & Zaldarriaga (2001) have recently re-examined the spatial power spectrum inferred from the APM survey and conclude that the 68% confidence interval of Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma (for n=1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1) is 0.19-0.370.190.37NUMBER:0.19 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.370.19-0.37, much larger than the range implied by equationÂ (11), and Efstathiou & Moody (2000) favor a lower central value (Î“â‰ˆ0.12Î“0.12Gamma RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.12\Gamma\approx 0.12, with 2â¢Ïƒ2ğœNUMBER:2 italic-sigma2\sigma range 0.05â‰¤Î“â‰¤0.380.05Î“0.38NUMBER:0.05 RELOP:less-than-or-equals Gamma RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.380.05\leq\Gamma\leq 0.38). As older estimates of the galaxy power spectrum are supplanted by results from the 2dF and Sloan galaxy redshift surveys, the Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma parameterization itself may become an insufficiently accurate representation of the theoretical predictions (percival01 ).

A detailed consideration of constraints from smaller scale CMB anisotropy measurements is beyond the scope of this paper, but we do want to draw on limits that smaller scale measurements place on the inflationary index nğ‘›italic-nn. For the no-tensor models, we adopt the â€œweak priorâ€ constraint n=0.96-0.09+0.10ğ‘›subscriptsuperscript0.960.100.09italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.96 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.09 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn=0.96^{+0.10}_{-0.09} of Netterfield et al.Â (2001), based on data from the BOOMERANG experiment, which we represent by the horizontal dot-dash line and 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bar in FigureÂ 4. Since Netterfield et al. (2001) do not consider models with tensor fluctuations, we take the corresponding constraint for the tensor models in FigureÂ 5 from Wang et al. (2001). Their model space is less restrictive than ours because they do not impose the power-law inflation relation T/S=7â¢(1-n)ğ‘‡ğ‘†71ğ‘›italic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n), and using CMB data alone they find only a very weak constraint on nğ‘›italic-nn. We therefore adopt their constraint from the combination of CMB and large scale structure data, n=0.91-0.05+0.07ğ‘›subscriptsuperscript0.910.070.05italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.91 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.07 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.05 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn=0.91^{+0.07}_{-0.05}, where we have reduced the 95% confidence range quoted in their tableÂ 2 by a factor of two to get a representative 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainty.

In FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, the cluster mass function, velocity power spectrum, and shape parameter constraints tend to be roughly parallel to each other, with the shape parameter following a somewhat different track when tensor fluctuations are important. The shape parameter constraint is usually compatible with the cluster mass function constraint, at least if one allows for the possibility that the error bar in equationÂ (11) is somewhat too small. However, the velocity power spectrum always implies a higher fluctuation amplitude than the cluster mass function, and the two constraints are not consistent within their stated 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties for any combination of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, nğ‘›italic-nn, and hâ„italic-hh. A recent analysis by Silberman et al. (2001) shows that the discrepancy is probably a result of non-linear effects on the velocity power spectrum, and that correcting for these yields results closer to the cluster constraint. We therefore regard the cluster constraint as more reliable, and we retain the velocity power spectrum curve mainly as a reminder of other data that can be brought to bear on these questions.

The LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) curve cuts across the other three constraints, requiring greater change in Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} for a given change in nğ‘›italic-nn. The CMB anisotropy limit on nğ‘›italic-nn cuts across all of the other constraints. The COBE-DMR measurement is represented implicitly in FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5 through its role in the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint, the velocity power spectrum constraint, and the CMB anisotropy constraint on nğ‘›italic-nn. The size of the 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars in these figures, and the probability that at least some of them are underestimated, prevents us from drawing sweeping conclusions. However, FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5 do have a number of suggestive implications if we look for models that lie within the overlapping 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties of the various constraints. Since it is not possible to satisfy the cluster mass function and velocity power spectrum constraints simultaneously within the class of models that we consider, the implications depend strongly on which of these constraints we take to be more reliable. The shape parameter implications are usually intermediate, but significantly closer to those of the cluster mass function.

The combination of the velocity power spectrum and LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraints implies a high density universe, with Î©mâ‰³1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}\gtrsim 1 preferred and Î©mâ‰²0.6less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.6\Omega_{m}\lesssim 0.6 separating the two constraints by more than their 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma error bars. The LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint rules out the high values of nğ‘›italic-nn that could otherwise allow low Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} in equationÂ (10). For hâ‰¥0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.65h\geq 0.65, intersection of the velocity power spectrum and LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraints occurs at nâ‰²0.8less-than-or-similar-toğ‘›0.8italic-n RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:0.8n\lesssim 0.8, incompatible with the CMB anisotropy constraint. However, an Î©mâˆ¼1similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}\sim 1 universe would require a low value of hâ„italic-hh in any case because of the age constraint for globular cluster stars, and this would push the intersection to higher nğ‘›italic-nn. As noted earlier, the velocity power spectrum constraint shown here is probably biased towards high Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{m} by the non-linear effects described by Silberman et al. (2001).

If we instead adopt the cluster mass function constraint, then consistency with the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and COBE requires Î©m<1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\Omega_{m}<1. For h=0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65, the constraints intersect at Î©mâˆ¼0.4-0.5similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.40.5Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.4 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.4-0.5 in flat models and Î©mâˆ¼0.5-0.6similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.50.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.5-0.6 in open models; increasing hâ„italic-hh slightly decreases the preferred Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and vice versa. This conclusion â€” that the combination of COBE, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function implies a low density universe â€” is the most important and robust result to emerge from this multi-constraint analysis.

At one level, our conclusions about the matter density come as no suprise, since we have already argued, in Weinberg et al.Â (1999), that consistency between the cluster mass function and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) implies Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} in this range independent of the COBE normalization. However, the nature of the argument is subtly different in this case. In Weinberg et al.Â (1999), we considered matter power spectra of the CDM form parameterized by Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma (with n=1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1n=1), and by combining the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement with the cluster constraintÂ (9), we found Î©m=0.34+1.3â¢(Î“-0.2)subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.341.3Î“0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.34 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1.3 OPEN:( Gamma ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.2 CLOSE:){\Omega_{m}}=0.34+1.3(\Gamma-0.2) for flat models and Î©m=0.46+1.3â¢(Î“-0.2)subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.461.3Î“0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.46 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1.3 OPEN:( Gamma ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.2 CLOSE:){\Omega_{m}}=0.46+1.3(\Gamma-0.2) for open models, with 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma uncertainties of about 0.10.1NUMBER:0.10.1. However, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) alone could not rule out the solution of high Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and high Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma, so Weinberg et al.â€™s (1999) conclusion that Î©m<1subscriptÎ©ğ‘š1Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1{\Omega_{m}}<1 rested crucially on the empirical evidence for Î“â‰ˆ0.2Î“0.2Gamma RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.2\Gamma\approx 0.2 from the shape of the galaxy power spectrum. Within the class of CDM models considered here, the combination of COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) determines nğ‘›italic-nn, and hence the effective value of Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma (eq.Â 11), once Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}, hâ„italic-hh, and Bğµitalic-BB are specified. Simultaneous consistency between COBE, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function requires low Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} independent of the galaxy power spectrum shape, thereby strengthening the overall argument for a low density universe, and, by the by, for a matter power spectrum with low Î“effsubscriptÎ“effGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff}. The lower limit on Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} from this combination of constraints varies with the choice of other parameters, but it never reaches as low as Î©m=0.2subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.2Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2{\Omega_{m}}=0.2 unless hâ‰¥0.85â„0.85italic-h RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.85h\geq 0.85.

For all of the models shown in FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and cluster mass function constraints intersect at values of nğ‘›italic-nn consistent with the CMB anisotropy constraints, provided one takes the 1-Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma error ranges into account. A factor of two improvement in the precision of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement could greatly restrict the range of models compatible with all three constraints, especially if the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) amplitude is somewhat lower, as McDonald et al. (2000) find.

There are, of course, numerous other constraints on cosmological parameters, and we will briefly consider three of them: the cluster baryon fraction, the location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB power spectrum, and the evidence for accelerating expansion from Type Ia supernovae. (Our focus on h=0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.65h=0.65 as a fiducial case already reflects our assessment of the most convincing direct estimates of H0subscriptğ»0italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{0}.) If one assumes that baryons are not overrepresented relative to their universal value within the virial radii of rich clusters, then the combination of the measured gas mass fractions with big bang nucleosynthesis limits on Î©bsubscriptÎ©ğ‘Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Omega_{b} yields an upper limit on Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} (white93b ). Applying this argument, Evrard (1997) concludes that

div.p: at the 95% confidence level. From FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5 we see that models matching COBE, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function are always consistent with this limit â€” easily in the case of flat models, sometimes marginally in the case of open models. Models that match the velocity power spectrum instead of the cluster mass function are usually incompatible with this limit, though sometimes only marginally so.

The location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB anisotropy spectrum is a strong diagnostic for space curvature (e.g., Doroshkevich (Zeldovich); wilson81 ; sugiyama92 ; Kamionkowski (Spergel); Hu et al.Â 1997), and recent anisotropy measurements on degree scales favor a geometry that is close to flat (e.g., miller99 ; melchiorri00 ; netterfield01 ; pryke01 ). Clearly our flat universe models are compatible with these results, as are the open universe models that match the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the velocity power spectrum (all of which have Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} close to one). The open models that match LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the cluster mass function are generally ruled out by the most recent, high precision limits on space curvature. The Type Ia supernova measurements of the cosmic expansion history (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ) add a great deal of discriminatory power, since they constrain a parameter combination that is roughly Î©m-Î©Î›subscriptÎ©ğ‘šsubscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}-{\Omega_{\Lambda}} instead of Î©m+Î©Î›subscriptÎ©ğ‘šsubscriptÎ©Î›Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}+{\Omega_{\Lambda}}; Perlmutter et al.Â (1999) quote Î©m-0.75â¢Î©Î›â‰ˆ-0.25Â±0.125subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.75subscriptÎ©Î›plus-or-minus0.250.125Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.75 Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.125{\Omega_{m}}-0.75{\Omega_{\Lambda}}\approx-0.25\pm 0.125. All of the open models miss this constraint by many Ïƒğœitalic-sigma\sigma, and the flat models matching the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) and the velocity power spectrum fail because the values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} are too high. The combination of COBE, the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), and the cluster mass function, on the other hand, is compatible with the supernova results for flat models with a cosmological constant, though it favors somewhat higher values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}}.

figure.figcaption:
Figure 6:
CMB anisotropy power spectra for five of the fiducial models that match COBE-DMR and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k). Clsubscriptğ¶ğ‘™italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{l} is the mean-squared amplitude of spherical harmonics of order lğ‘™italic-ll. The models shown are Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM (solid), Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM2 (dotted), OCDM (long-dashed), TCDM (short-dashed), and CHDM (dot-dashed). Parameters of the models are listed in TableÂ 1. Data points with 1â¢Ïƒ1ğœNUMBER:1 italic-sigma1\sigma errors are taken from Wang et al. (2001). We shift from logarithmic spacing to linear spacing at l=100ğ‘™100italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:100l=100 in order to show both large and small angular scales clearly.

div.p: All in all, the CWPHK and McDonald et al.Â (2000) measurements of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) provide additional support for the current â€œconsensusâ€ model of structure formation, Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM with Î©mâ‰ˆ0.4subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.4Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.4{\Omega_{m}}\approx 0.4 and hâ‰ˆ0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.65h\approx 0.65. Moderate improvements in the statistical precision of the constraints considered here could strengthen this support, or they could open fissures of disagreement. Improvements in the near future could also allow some interesting new tests, such as discriminating between models with no tensor fluctuations and models with the T/S=7â¢(1-n)ğ‘‡ğ‘†71ğ‘›italic-T MULOP:divide italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:7 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-n CLOSE:)T/S=7(1-n) contribution predicted by power law inflation.

A detailed consideration of the constraints from CMB anisotropy measurements is a major undertaking in itself, well beyond the scope of this paper. However, to illustrate the interplay between our results and recent CMB experiments, we plot in FigureÂ 6 the predicted CMB power spectra of five of our fiducial models: Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM, Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM2, OCDM, TCDM, and CHDM. We computed these power spectra using CMBFAST (seljak96 ; Zaldarriaga (Seljak)), with the cosmological parameter values listed in TableÂ 1. The CHDM model stands out from the rest because matching the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) requires a high value of nğ‘›italic-nn, which boosts the anisotropy on small scales. The OCDM model also stands out, albeit less dramatically, because the open space geometry shifts the acoustic peaks to smaller angles. The TCDM model lies below the Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM models because of its larger tilt, which suppresses small scale fluctuations. FigureÂ 6 shows data points taken from the joint analysis of numerous CMB data sets by Wang et al. (2001; see their Table 1). The two Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM models fit these data points remarkably well, given that the choice of their parameters was not based on small scale CMB data at all. Because the combination of COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) implies nğ‘›italic-nn close to one for both of these models, their predictions are not very different, and the current CMB data do not distinguish between them. However, the TCDM, OCDM, and CHDM models are clearly ruled out, and while we have not attempted to adjust their parameters within the constraints allowed by equationsÂ (7) andÂ (8), it appears unlikely that any such adjustment would allow these models to fit the current CMB data.

The slope of the mass power spectrum inferred by CWPHK from the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest, Î½=-2.25Â±0.18ğœˆplus-or-minus2.250.18italic-nu RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.18
u=-2.25\pm 0.18 at kp=0.008â¢(kmâ¢s-1)-1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘0.008superscriptkmsuperscripts11italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.008 OPEN:( km s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk_{p}=0.008\;({m{km\;s^{-1}\;}})^{-1} at z=2.5ğ‘§2.5italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5z=2.5, confirms one of the basic predictions of the inflationary CDM scenario: an approximately scale-invariant spectrum of primeval inflationary fluctuations (nâ‰ˆ1ğ‘›1italic-n RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:1n\approx 1) modulated by a transfer function that bends the power spectrum towards Pâ¢(k)âˆkn-4proportional-toğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›4italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP(k)\propto k^{n-4} on small scales. If the measured slope of the power spectrum had implied Î½>-2ğœˆ2italic-nu RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2
u>-2 or Î½<-2.5ğœˆ2.5italic-nu RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.5
u<-2.5, we would have been unable to reproduce the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) with any of the models considered here, even allowing wide variations in the cosmological parameters.

Because the amplitude of the COBE-normalized power spectrum on small scales is very sensitive to nğ‘›italic-nn, we are able to match the CWPHK measurement of Î”2â¢(kp)superscriptÎ”2subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Delta^{2}(k_{p}) in most of the major variants of the CDM scenario (Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM, OCDM, TCDM, CHDM) by treating nğ‘›italic-nn as a free parameter. Within each of these variants, we obtain constraints on the model parameters of the form Î©mâ¢hÎ±â¢nÎ²â¢BÎ³=kÂ±ÏµsubscriptÎ©ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ›¼superscriptğ‘›ğ›½superscriptğµğ›¾plus-or-minusğ‘˜italic-ÏµOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilon{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}B^{\gamma}=k\pm\epsilon (eq.Â 7) or Î©mâ¢hÎ±â¢nÎ²â¢BÎ³â¢Î©Î½Î´=kÂ±ÏµsubscriptÎ©ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ›¼superscriptğ‘›ğ›½superscriptğµğ›¾superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğœˆğ›¿plus-or-minusğ‘˜italic-ÏµOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-B POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-k ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-epsilon{\Omega_{m}}h^{\alpha}n^{\beta}B^{\gamma}{\Omega_{\nu}}^{\delta}=k\pm\epsilon (eq.Â 8), with the parameter values listed in TableÂ 2. These constraints, together with the confirmation of the predicted slope, are the main results to emerge from combining the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) measurement with the COBE-DMR result.

As shown in FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5, the parameter combination constrained by COBE and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) is different from the combinations constrained by other measurements of large scale structure and CMB anisotropy, so joint consideration of these constraints can break some of the degeneracies among the fundamental parameters. If we combine the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) constraint with the constraint on Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘šOmega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\Omega_{m}} and Ïƒ8subscriptğœ8italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:8 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{8} inferred from the cluster mass function (White et al.Â 1993a; ECF), then we favor a low density universe, with Î©mâˆ¼0.3-0.5similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.30.5Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.3-0.5 in flat models and Î©mâˆ¼0.5-0.6similar-tosubscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.50.6Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.6{\Omega_{m}}\sim 0.5-0.6 in open models. This combination is also consistent with CMB anisotropy constraints on nğ‘›italic-nn. The open models are inconsistent with the angular location of the first acoustic peak in the CMB power spectrum (netterfield01 ; pryke01 ), and they are strongly inconsistent with Type Ia supernova results, which imply Î©m-0.75â¢Î©Î›â‰ˆ-0.25Â±0.125subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.75subscriptÎ©Î›plus-or-minus0.250.125Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.75 Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.125{\Omega_{m}}-0.75{\Omega_{\Lambda}}\approx-0.25\pm 0.125 (riess98 ; perlmutter99 ). The flat models are consistent with both constraints. On the whole, the CWPHK measurement of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) supports the consensus in favor of Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM with Î©mâ‰ˆ0.4subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.4Omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.4{\Omega_{m}}\approx 0.4, hâ‰ˆ0.65â„0.65italic-h RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.65h\approx 0.65. The contribution of the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) to this consensus comes both from the slope, which confirms the generic inflationary CDM prediction, and from the amplitude, which has a different dependence on cosmological parameters than any of the other constraints considered here.

There are bright prospects for improvements of this approach in the near future. McDonald et al.Â (2000) have inferred the mass power spectrum from an independent LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ forest data set using a different analysis method, obtaining a nearly identical slope and an amplitude lower by âˆ¼1â¢Ïƒsimilar-toabsent1ğœRELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 italic-sigma\sim 1\sigma. We have recently analyzed a much larger data set of high and moderate resolution spectra, using a variant of the Croft et al.Â (1998, 1999) method, and the improved data yield much higher statistical precision and better tests for systematic effects. Constraints from this new measurement of Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k), using the method developed here, are presented in Â§7 of Croft et al. (2001). Recent measurements of CMB anisotropy have greatly improved the level of precision on small angular scales, and results from the MAP satellite should provide another major advance in the near future. These measurements yield tighter cosmological parameter constraints on their own, but they become substantially more powerful when combined with data that constrain the shape and amplitude of the matter power spectrum. It is evident from FiguresÂ 4 andÂ 5 that simply reducing the error bars on nğ‘›italic-nn and the LyÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alphaÂ Pâ¢(k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜italic-P OPEN:( italic-k CLOSE:)P(k) by a factor of two would already produce interesting new restrictions on the allowable range of models. These restrictions can become very powerful if ongoing studies of cluster masses using galaxy dynamics, X-ray properties, the Sunyaev-Zelâ€™dovich effect, and gravitational lensing confirm the robustness of the cluster mass function constraint. In the slightly longer term, the 2dF and Sloan redshift surveys should produce measurements of the shape of the galaxy power spectrum that shrink the current statistical and systematic uncertainties, so that demanding consistency between the inferred value of Î“effsubscriptÎ“effGamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start eff POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{\rm eff} and other constraints becomes a useful additional test. At the very least, these developments should lead to a powerful test of the inflationary CDM picture and high-precision determinations of its parameters. If we are lucky, improved measurements will reveal deficiencies of the simplest Î›Î›Lambda\LambdaCDM models that are hidden within the current uncertainties, and resolving these discrepancies will lead us to a better understanding of the cosmic energy contents and the origin of primordial fluctuations in the hot early universe.
